awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Intentionally Nonlinear Design of High-frequency Atomic Force Microscopy for Enhanced Material Characterization
awd_abstract_narration:
Since its development in the early 1980s, atomic force microscopy (AFM) has been one of the most useful imaging tools in the fields of nano- and biosciences. This award supports theoretical and experimental studies of a new type of AFM realized through constructive use of intentional nonlinear resonance enabling the utilization of high-frequency measurements for sensing. Apart from proving the efficacy of the concept of constructive utilization of intentional nonlinearity in nano/micro designs to achieve performance not otherwise attainable, in a broader sense this project's approach can act as a testbed for assessing how strong nonlinearity incorporated into a complex mechanical system can lead to drastic performance gains. This work can be potentially transformative, since it can provide a new paradigm of intentionally nonlinear AFM technology based on higher-frequency sensing, with demonstrated capacity for drastically enhanced sensitivity and performance. The gained AFM sensing capability will be an incomparable tool in fields such as nano- and bio-sciences.

Detailed analytical, computational and experimental studies will be performed of a new, microcantilever beam design enabling higher-frequency nonlinear AFM. Under dynamic mode operation an intentionally designed 1:n internal resonance between the two leading bending modes of the AFM microcantilever incorporating an inner Silicon paddle, leads to magnification of high-frequency harmonics in the paddle response, which is the basis for AFM of improved sensitivity. The research team will develop the significantly enhanced AFM measurements of sample material properties and topography, achieved through sensing of higher harmonics in the response. The research team will systematically study, optimize, extend and validate this promising concept through theoretical studies to characterize the paddle's response to different types of interaction forces, and will perform an extended series of experimental tests to assess the sensitivity of high-order internal resonance designs to changes in topology and material properties. Moreover, multi-paddle AFM designs incorporating multiple simultaneous internal resonances will be analyzed for quantitative characterization, whereas related microfabrication issues will also be addressed.

por.por_cntn:
Atomic Force Microscopy (AFM) has been widely utilized to gain insight into various material and structural functionalities on the small scale, leading to numerous discoveries and new technologies. This project developed a radically new way for performing AFM. The aim was to characterise the topology and the material properties of samples in the micro- and nano-scales. Traditional AFM approaches are based on the concept of linear resonance of a microcantilever; as such, the performed measurements of the properties of the sample are in narrow frequency ranges. On the contrary, the AFM designs  that were developed in this project are intristically nonlinear, and, as such, have the capacity for broadband frequency operation. Moreover, it is now possible to perform measurements of the properties of the sample simultaneously at multiple frequencies (which was not possible in traditional methods), and so to enhance drastically the sensitivity and accuracy of the AFM operation.

In this research project a new type of paddled micro-cantilever devices was designed, fabricated and successfully tested. Strong nonlinearity in these devices was achieved  by the activation of nonlinear internal resonance between two or more vibration modes of the cantilever-paddle assembly, thus inducing energy transfers from lower to higher frequencies. This resulted in magnification of higher frequency harmonics in the measured data, which, in turn, enebled drasticaly better characterization of the sample properties.

Diverse applications were considered. First, it was demostrated that the parformance of the new paddled cantilever design can be optimized. AFM scans of cyanobacteriaare were taken, and the higher mode observables (amplitude and phase) enabled the characterization of stiffness variations that could not be otherwise detected by the topographical data. Hence, it was demonstrated that the developed new design enabled a significant enhancement in AFM functionality.

In addition, a new mass sensing scheme was proposed, where amplitude shifts within a nonlinear resonance serve as indicators for mass detection in the microscale. An unexpected and surprising finding of this aspect of the research was the detection of nonlinear ultra-broadband  resonance in appropriately designed micro- or nano-resonators excited by harmonic base excitation. This important effect was analytically predicted and experimentally verified for the first time during the course of the project. In addition, ultra-broadband nonlinear resonance was implemented to the design of a mass sensing device, yielding strong amplificationof of the third harmonic in the sensor’s response. In turn, this enhanced the mass sensing senitivity, the robustness and the operational envelope of the proposed design. It is noted that his new type of open loop mass sensing avoids complex feedback control and time-consuming frequency sweeping. Moreover,the mass resolution is within a functional range, and the design parameters are reasonable from a manufacturing perspective.

Finally, a basic current limitation of AFM wss addressed, namely, the simultaneous characterization of topological and functional properties of materials, which suffers from the crosstalk between the observables, causing undesirable artifacts and complicated interpretations. To this end, a two-field AFM probe ws developed integrating two discrete measurement pathways such that they respond independently to the variations in surface topography and material functionality. This allowed for reliable determination of functional properties. The efficacy of the proposed design has been demonstrated via Piezoresponse Force Microscopy (PFM) of periodically poledlithium niobate (PPLN) and collagen, but its potential applications are much broader, e.g., it can also be applied to AFM-based Infrared Spectroscopy (AFM-IR) and Electrochemical Strain Microscopy (ESM).

In a more general context, the developed approach promotes a new paradigm in design, namely, the intentional implementation of strong nonlinearity in micro- and nano-devices with the aim of achieving drastically improved and heretofore unavailable functionality and performance.
